metadata.title: Small Data, and Getting It. The Motion of the Ocean | by Robert Boscacci | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Big data is fine and good: As the sample size of our dataset (n) approaches infinity, we can make increasingly confident and general assertions, based on increasingly nuanced aberrations and trends…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Topographic Representation of Numerosity in the Human Parietal Cortex
Our Brains Have a Map for Numbers
Why Small Data is the Future of AI
Small Data: The Tiny Clues that Uncover Huge Trends

all_paragraphs: Big data is fine and good: As the sample size of our dataset (n) approaches infinity, we can make increasingly confident and general assertions, based on increasingly nuanced aberrations and trends in that data.

Large sample sizes are major key in many contexts, e.g. rocket science: Precision is king, academic reputations are at stake, and crossing some statistical confidence threshold might validate a lifetime of investigation into something as pivotal to our existence as, like, the big bang theory:
As great as Big Data is, there’s also a case to be made for Small Data (with purposely ironic capital letters), and here I’ll add to the choir making it.
Big Data can be too big for some applications, such as intuitive conceptualization and storytelling. There’s also the fact that there are barriers to acquiring huge datasets of high quality.
Here I quote Scientific American’s Emilie Reas, who references “Topographic Representation of Numerosity in the Human Parietal Cortex” in her piece “Our Brains Have a Map for Numbers”:

[There is] a small brain area [which] represents numerosity along a continuous “map.” Just as we organize numbers along a mental “number line,” with one at the left, increasing in magnitude to the right, so is quantity mapped onto space in the brain. One side of this brain region responds to small numbers, the adjacent region to larger numbers, and so on, with numeric representations increasing to the far end.
[These Researchers at Utrecht University in the Netherlands] found that the parietal cortex map represented relative, not absolute, quantities.

While considering currency in factors of ten, for example, all we care about are more or less commas. We don’t visualize the correct-sized pile of hundred dollar bills while pricing something expensive, we just compare with the market price (essentially just a symbol, not even a number we can conceptualize) of other similar things. We understand deltas. We feeble beings have to abstract large (sets of) numbers away to external apparatuses in order to manipulate, and especially to derive meaning. We reduce dimensions, we bin, and we plot data to bring it down to a scale we can digest and act upon. We make Big Data small, to see it and its implicit patterns.

McDonalds stopped publishing the number after they sold their 99 Billionth burger. Nobody cares anymore. They just threw a “greater than” sign in front of the 99 Billion. Seinfeld has a bit about this. He gets it. Another 10–15 Billion sold isn’t going to alter my perception of McDonald’s.

Stalin was sort of right about statistics. While I disagree, in that a million deaths is definitely very tragic, I agree that people have a hard time visualizing big numbers, aggregates, and averages. These don’t emotionally move us quite the same way that individual accounts (backed by their accompanying small data) do.
In October 2013, 5-time CMO Allen Bonde goes to the Digital Pulse Summit, hosts a panel on “Small Data,” and comes back with this definition:

Small data connects people with timely, meaningful insights (derived from big data and / or “local” sources), organized and packaged — often visually — to be accessible, understandable, and actionable for everyday tasks.

I want to focus not on the practice of making big data small, because we do this plenty already with visualization libraries in python, but rather more on the increasing relevance of small-batch, locally-sourced (dare I say artisanal? Am I a wannabe dirty Brooklyn hipster?) data, and highlight its personal component. Small Data has a greater capacity for individual relevance and emotional weight than Big Data. Just because we can’t run the most advanced, sample-hungry machine learning models on a dataset doesn’t make it meaningless! (I tell myself this now, just as a bread-crumb, right before I learn how to leverage neural nets and stuff in a couple weeks.)

In the LitHub article “Small Data is the New Big Data,” Marta Bausells writes this: In “Dear Data, a collection of illustrated postcards representing their artistic, personal takes on seemingly mundane data collected over a year of their lives,” Giorgia Lupi and Stefanie Posavec write this:
Data collected from life can be a snapshot of the world in the same way that a picture catches small moments in time.

Lupi and Posavec reclaim that poetic granularity of the individual from the homogenizing aggregate-grip of Big Data. What emerges is a case for the beauty of small data and its deliberate interpretation, analog visualization, and slow transmission — a celebration of the infinitesimal, incomplete, imperfect, yet marvelously human details through which we wrest meaning out of the incomprehensible vastness of all possible experience that is life.

Some of my Data Science bootcamp classmates and I have Jaime Cheng to thank for bringing us all to hear Lupi speak about Dear Data, and Small Data more generally, at Columbia University, in conjunction with The Pudding.

As a recovering film industry worker and lover of low-budget independent films, I hold that there is magic in the mundane: Some of the most profound and relatable truths about human nature and society can only be seen at the individual, normal human scale, which is, like, why I can’t stand superhero films. Let’s be honest, señor Dynamite here is more relatable than Tony Stark.
The metaphor begins to deteriorate, so we’ll move on.

While parable in its many forms is one of the principal vehicles for moral and behavioral influence (ahem advertising), Small Data’s applications are not strictly limited to storytelling: In his Medium post “Why Small Data is the Future of AI,” Bradley Arsenault argues that companies might have to deal with small data soon anyhow, because:

Many artificial intelligence companies that are working on truly novel solutions have to gather the data sets for those solutions manually. A huge portion of the capital investment into an artificial intelligence startup is put into gathering the dataset necessary to make their product work.
If you can make your machine learning model(s) work well with small data, then you can save time and money on research, surveying, experimenting, or whatever it is you do to generate data.

One of the hardest parts of Data Science is getting our hands on good data to work with (and munging it). Data scrounged from the nether regions of the interweb doesn’t always inspire confidence regarding its methods of collection and organization. Maybe it’s old and crusty. Data provided by an employer might be incomplete, unusable, or simply non-existent.
Maybe we’ve been inspired by the creators of Dear Data, and we want to try our hand at collecting our own, you know, for fun and sport. How do we get it? Let’s get it.
I tweet to Lupi to ask how she collects her Small Data:

By hand? If you’re as talented as Giorgia you can leverage that analog charm to sell a fortune’s worth of coffee table books, but I’m not that talented. I don’t see the point in an intermediate analog step when I know I’m going to be working in pandas and visualizing my data on the online, and I can’t draw.
Using a spreadsheet? Sure, but what about saving GPS data? I’d rather do my data collection on a mobile device, and navigating spreadsheets on a mobile device is un-fun.

I like this idea of purpose-built data collection apps. I’m on an android phone though, so Lupi’s recommendation, Reporter, doesn’t work for me. I go looking for alternatives and come up with surprisingly little. There’s an android-compatible data collection app called Collect by SocialCops, but their prices scare me. I’m not a fully funded NGO over here.
This is when I discover Open Data Kit (ODK), “an open and welcoming community of people just like you!” Their android data collection tool ODK Collect looks very promising.

ODK Collect is a unwieldy at first: It’s an open source community project, not a polished consumer app, so you do have to read a little documentation and familiarize yourself with it before you can get started logging data. (I filed a bug report relating to location services, and was met with an invitation to fix it myself..! Open source indeed. I’ll make it happen as soon as I find a free week to learn the Android development environment.)
Here’s a quick-start in ODK for Small-Data collecting:

The nice thing about ODK Collect is that you can hook it up to Google Docs: By setting the submission_url in your blank form spreadsheet’s settings tab, you can have every form submission auto-populate to a row in a google sheet. We can rest easy that our data is backed up in the cloud, and later it will be trivial to download/import this as an xls or csv in Pandas.
Here are some screengrabs of my form as I fill it out in ODK Collect:

I submit my filled-out form, and my google sheet is configured to auto-populate, so the data appears—complete with lat/long coordinates, boolean values, floats, timestamps, and a uid. You can really trick out your forms.
Then we can bring it full circle, downloading the spreadsheet data as a .csv or .xls and importing into pandas (in a jupyter notebook):

Much smoother than pen and clipboard, and sustainable! Any number of fully trained, qualified data collectors could be out surveying with this form, all populating the same spreadsheet. I should mention that ODK is geared towards data collection off-the-grid: You can use this tool with or without cel data, in remote locations, wherever there are important humanitarian projects to undertake.

Another way to go about collecting survey data, which might be more obvious, would be to crowdsource it by sending out a google form. These are very easy to create and send out en masse. The responses roll in, there are nice little visualizations right in the web app, and you can of course coerce the data into spreadsheet form with the click of a button for download and further investigation.

One drawback of sending out an email or web survey is that you’re then trusting respondents to submit accurate information, which may not always be the case: You might substitute quality for quantity, which is not in the spirit of Small Data!

Volumes and volumes have been written about how to collect data properly. Know that there is a wrong way to survey. As in so many arenas, even if you have the technology to do it efficiently, you might be doing it wrong efficiently. Don’t do that. Read more than just this blog post before you go.
I hope this inspires Data Scientists across disciplines and at various skill levels to consider creating their own little datasets—and create them with love! c:
“There is even a marketing research book by Martin Lindstrom, Small Data: The Tiny Clues that Uncover Huge Trends,” mentions Gary Klein, Ph.D., writing for Psychology Today.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Author of “The Spring of Sight”, expected publication late 2022
